posts.name: rod@3711
posts.cooked:
Has anyone been able to do position control of a PG71 gearmotor using the REV Hardware Client?

I have successfully played with position control of the NEO brushless motor.

When I switched to a brushed motor, with Sensor Type=No Sensor and Alternate Encoder selected, it gives a Sensor Fault.  I can spin the brushed motor with the Run-Percent command.  No response with Position Control.

I loaded the Alternate Encoder example Java program, and configured it for a Brushed motor.  It did not do PID positioning.

I altered the program to directly run the motor and to display the encoder and it all worked as expected.

Finally I added code for a simple PID control and it worked, but we would rather use the Smart Max controls

Can the Smart Max do PID control of a brushed motor?
How is the encoder connected to the SparkMax?

posts.name: rod@3711
posts.cooked: Data Port.  encoder A to pin 6 and encoder B to pin 8.  I assume that is good, since the Alternate Encoder example program reads the encoder.
There should be a feedbackSensor config or something like that somewhere

posts.name: rod@3711
posts.cooked: I have wasted about 2 days trying to get this to work.  Has anyone every used a Smart Max controller to do PID control of a brushed motor?

posts.name: Will Toth
posts.cooked:
rod1:

brushed motor, with Sensor Type=No Sensor and Alternate Encoder selected

In brushed mode I would recommend using the regular encoder instead of the ‘alternate encoder’. The wiring for that is slightly different, but it does not have the same RPM restrictions as alternate encoder mode, and more important, shouldn’t give you a sensor fault.

posts.name: rod@3711
posts.cooked:
Thanks, I will try that today.

I am trying to use existing pg and vex motors, but I think my final solution will be to buy ION gear sets for a NEO motors.

posts.name: rod@3711
posts.cooked: Still no luck getting Smart Max PID control of a brushed motor.  Ordered $1000 of gearboxes for bushless motors.

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
The hall encoder in the PG71 gives a standard quadrature signal. There should be no problems connecting it to and using it with a SPARK MAX in brushed mode. You also seem a little confused by what the white line is; it’s exclusively used as a third phase of power in brushless mode. It’s not related to the sensors at all, and in brushed mode it’s unused.

This thread is a month old. The OP has likely moved on.
I was. Thank you for the correction!
